tossups.question: A ruler of this dynasty, nicknamed “the Brilliant,” created a code of laws called the Regulations of the Royal Court and used the execution of a prince called Chuban as a pretext to rebel against Abu Sa’id Khan. Despite his nickname of “the Great”, a ruler of this non-Macedonian dynasty named Alexander disintegrated his kingdom after he appointed his three sons as co-rulers and abdicated to become a monk. With help from local Kipchaks, a ruler of this dynasty leading monaspa calvary encircled a Seljuk army, aided by the title mountain, at the Battle of (*) Didgori. The upper classes of this dynasty, called the eristavi and aznauri, were at the top of the patronqmoba feudal system. This dynasty ruled three kingdoms of Kakheti, Imerti, and Kartli after their country fractured under invasions from the Mongols and Timurids.  For 10 points, identify this dynasty, whose members like Tamar the Great and David the Builder ruled medieval Georgia.

A member of this family decries the Japanese as “sandal-wearing goldfish-tenders” after accusing an employee of stealing from him. That member of this family had earlier held a dance where he demanded that the band add a fourth beat to the “Blue Danube Waltz”, the resulting confusion of which allows another character to escape with his slave Virgil. A member of this family is shown laughing in the shower, church, and while asleep after reminiscing about crippling an Irish laborer with a bumper car in his youth. That member of this family uses “glower power” to scare off a group of hippies protesting his (*) germ warfare research facility. After a member of this family abandoned it as a child, a teddy bear named Bobo is owned by Charles Lindbergh and Hitler before being found by Bart Simpson. For 10 points, identify this family whose most famous member owns the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant.
tossups.answer: Burns family (accept Mr. Burns; accept Charles Montgomery Burns; accept Wainwright Montgomery Burns)
tossups.metadata: accept Mr. Burns; accept Charles Montgomery Burns; accept Wainwright Montgomery Burns

tossups.question: The lyrics to an unofficial national anthem of this country were apocryphally written in response to their author witnessing a foreign soldier beating up a shopkeeper. A foreign power increased the capacity of an important railroad in this country by connecting it to the Karun River. Prior to his service at the Battle of Monte Cassino, Wojtek, a Syrian brown bear, was “recruited” by the exiled Polish Anders’ Army as it passed through this country. To ensure control of this country’s (*) oil and supply lines, an Anglo-Soviet invasion of this country deposed its ruler and installed his son in Operation Countenance. Operation Long Jump was a Nazi attempt to assassinate the “Big Three” at a conference in this country. For 10 points, name this country which hosted the Tehran Conference.

A city was renamed after a leader of this country-specific party after he negotiated the creation of the VAZ automobile plant. That leader of this party was shot three times by a fascist student in 1948, but survived. Meliorism was a faction of this party, and in 1977 a member of this party, Luciano Lama, denounced the autonomist movement. In 1991, this party dissolved itself in a “turning point” and re-formed as the Democratic Party of the Left. Under the leadership of Enrico (*) Berlinguer, it entered into a “Historic Compromise” with a Christian Democratic party from 1976 to 1980. This party was the largest of its kind in post-WWII western Europe, and after one of its founders was jailed in 1926, he formulated concepts such as the subaltern and cultural hegemony in his Prison Notebooks. For 10 points, name this organization that was led by Palmiro Togliatti and Antonio Gramsci, a Marxist-Leninist party.
tossups.answer: Italian Communist Party (accept Partita Comunista Italiano, accept PCI, accept equivalents mentioning “Communism” and “Italy”. The city is Tolyatti in Russia.)
tossups.metadata: accept Partita Comunista Italiano, accept PCI, accept equivalents mentioning “Communism” and “Italy”. The city is Tolyatti in Russia.

tossups.question: Information detailing the boundaries, landscape, and history of the land in and around this kingdom, while common knowledge for its residents, was held in secret for outsiders in books known as kadaim. In recognition of Dutch assistance against another European power, Vimala Dharma Suriya I of this kingdom supposedly said “[this kingdom] is now Flanders” after meeting with Joris van Spilbergen. An object most commonly associated with this kingdom was under the care of the position of Diyawadana Nilame. The (*) Uva Rebellion sought to reverse the 1815 annexation of this kingdom. This kingdom came to power after the fall of the Kingdom of Kotte and was the last major native state in its region before British rule. For 10 points, what is this Sri Lankan kingdom famous for holding a tooth of the Buddha?

The HMS Raccoon was part of an expedition sent to take a fort in this modern state during the War of 1812, but arrived to find that the fort had already been sold to a British company. A disagreement over the payment of a horse between the Wasco man Cockstock and the freed black man James Saules was an important factor in two separate laws banning African-Americans from moving to this modern state. Political organization in this modern state developed out of a series of “wolf meetings” held in its town of Champoeg (“sham-poo”-ee). It’s not Hawaii, but the chief Naukane was sent by (*) Kamehameha I to look after Hawaiians traveling on the Tonquin to a fort in this modern state. Built to facilitate trapping in the area, Fort Astoria was the first American settlement in this modern state. For 10 points, what is this modern state whose Willamette Valley was the endpoint of a namesake trail?
tossups.answer: Oregon (accept Oregon Territory or Oregon Country)
tossups.metadata: accept Oregon Territory or Oregon Country

tossups.question: A council called to support this belief was later called the “Headless Council” because no church officials of sufficient importance were in attendance. A governor, whom some later sources simply called “the Dragon” to liken him to the beasts of the Book of Revelation, allegedly forced monks and nuns to marry each other in a stadium to stifle opposition to this belief. An argument levied against this belief was the miraculous appearance of acheiropoieta. Much of Calabria and Sicily was removed from papal authority after (*) Pope Gregory III convened two synods in Rome in the same year to oppose this belief. St. Catherine’s Monastery in Egypt contains many works that were unaffected by this belief, including an early mosaic of Christ Pantocrator. For 10 points, identify this belief, most famously held by Byzantine Emperor Leo III, that seeks the destruction of religious imagery.

A later Incan story claims that the extensive systems for acquiring this resource at Pikillaqta (“pee-keel”-YAHK-tah) were created for the hand of the maiden Sumac Tica. Robert Bradley has argued that the lack of this resource at the site of Kuelap (KWAY-lap) suggests that it was not a fortress, but rather a settlement for elites that was supplied by nearby villages. Control over this resource is what defined local social hierarchies, now called parcialidades, throughout much of Pre-Columbian Peru. The Nazca Culture constructed underground puquios to store this resource. The suka qullu (“sue”-kah “cool-you”) system used this resource to keep (*) crops insulated from freezing temperatures. With corn, this resource is used to make chicha. As well as keeping soil in place, the use of andén (ahn-DAYN) terraces kept this resource from flowing down hillsides. For 10 points, name this resource gathered from places like the Moche River and Lake Titicaca.

A lavish tent that was to host an important ceremony during an event in this city was burnt down during the rehearsal by a cigarette butt, requiring a new one to be hastily made. A series of military exercises in this city is one of two extant portions of a Kinemacolor film made by Charles Urban. Plans for George VI to impress the “native minds” of this city by traveling to it via plane to hold a grand ceremony at Coronation Park were dropped because of their lack of political or financial tact. A royal proclamation given in this city announced the reversal of the first (*) Partition of Bengal. The construction of a new section of this city by Edward Lutyens began during a 1911 durbar [duhr-“BAR”] celebrating the accession of George V. For 10 points, identify this city, the last capital of the British Raj and the current one of India.

One designer of these things left CDC after the STAR-100 project stalled. One model of these things had a “waterfall” cooling system that used Fluorinert. A company that produces these things was acquired by SGI, and that company developed the Y-MP and X-MP models under the oversight of Steve Chen. The LINPACK test is conducted on these things, and Gordon and Comet are located in a “center” for these things in UC San Diego. These things are ranked by the (*) TOP500 list, and some of these objects engineered by Seymour Cray have a C-shaped design. Several of these things have broken the Pentascale barrier. Examples of these objects include Atlas and ILLIAC, and the performance of these things is often measured in FLOPs, or Floating-point Operations per Second. For 10 points, name these objects, some of which include IBM’s Deep Blue and Watson.
tossups.answer: Supercomputers (prompt on “Computers”; do not accept or prompt on “PC” or “Personal Computer”)
tossups.metadata: prompt on “Computers”; do not accept or prompt on “PC” or “Personal Computer”

tossups.question: Fortifications that once defended this city included Guînes and Hammes. At the Battle of Ludford Bridge, a “Master Porter” from this city, Andrew Trollope, defected to the Lancastrians. In the wake of that battle, a future king fled with the Nevilles to this city. The Earl of Warwick was a “captain” of this city. After the loss of this city to the Duke of Guise in 1558, Mary I reportedly said that when she was buried, she would have this city (*) “lying in her heart”. After the Treaty of Brétigny, a namesake “Pale” was set up around this city, which was a center of medieval wool imports from England. In the wake of the Battle of Crécy, Edward III captured this city, but spared its inhabitants after six of its prominent citizens volunteered for execution. For 10 points, name this northern French port city, whose “Burghers” were commemorated in a Rodin sculpture.

His response to a Mongol invasion of this modern country earned a ruler of one kingdom the epithet “he who flees from the ‘Turk’”. After Felipe de Brito used his governorship of the city of Syriam to make a de facto independent pirate state, a ruler of a kingdom in this modern country massacred the Portuguese settlers at Dianga to prevent further betrayals. Following his defeat at the Battle of Khajwa, Shah Shuja fled to a kingdom in this modern country, where conflict over his wealth with King Sanda Thudhamma led to Shuja’s death. (*) Maung Htaw Lay was an influential official in this modern country who protected its Shwedagon Pagoda from British troops using it as a fort. Following the Sepoy Rebellion, Bahadur Shah II was exiled to Rangoon in, for 10 points, what modern country that formed the easternmost portion of British India?

Yuko Hakateyama slit her throat as an act of penance for Japan after one of her fellow countrymen attempted to assassinate an official from this country. In an attempt to free a diplomat from this country, prominent merchant Takadaya Kahei was captured by Peter Rikord in 1812. The merchant Dembei was the first Japanese person to travel to the capital of this country. The first official agreement between Japan and this country was the Treaty of Shimoda. It’s not China, but the Treaty of (*) San Francisco has fueled an ongoing dispute between Japan and this country over islands such as Etorofu and Kunashiri. This country suffered a massive defeat at the hands of the Japanese Navy at the Battle of Tsushima. For 10 points, name this country who still disputes ownership of the Kuril Islands with Japan.

Description acceptable  After a leader in this event expressed distaste for doves, “Princess of Porcelain” Helen Boehm created a sculpture of two mute swans called The Bird of Peace, which was gifted during this event. Max Frankel won a Pulitzer Prize for his coverage of this event. Winston Lord was cut out of pictures of a meeting during this event to avoid embarrassing a high-ranking official who was excluded from it. This event was arranged through both sides relations with (*) Yahya Khan’s government. This event resulted in the issuing of the first of the Three Communiqués. A meeting between Glenn Cowan and Zhuāng Zédòng was the start of “ping pong diplomacy”, which began the year before this event. For 10 points, identify this 1972 event in which the 37th president of the US traveled to the world’s most populous country.
tossups.answer: Richard M. Nixon’s visit to China (accept any answer that says that Nixon is in China)
acceptable: Richard M. Nixon’s visit to China
tossups.metadata: accept any answer that says that Nixon is in China

tossups.question: A punitive naval raiding expedition during this man’s reign may have aided the Slavic siege of Patras. After a protracted theological debate with this man and multiple imprisonments, some sources claim that the seventh Shi’a Imam, Mūsa ibn Ja’far al-Kāzim, was poisoned by this man. Though quickly ignored, a peace term after this man’s second large campaign against the Byzantines was the imposition of the jizya on Emperor Nikephoros I and his son. This ruler split his lands between his sons (*) al-Mu’min and al-Amin, setting the stage for the Fourth Fitna. As well as destroying the political power of the Barmakids, this ruler sent a mechanical clock and the elephant Abul-Abbas as gifts to Charlemagne. For 10 points, identify this man, an Abbasid Caliph in the late 8th century who features prominently in the One Thousand and One Nights.

Statutes promulgated by this leader at Thionville and Abbeville reorganized his army into troops “of the ordinance”. This leader’s territorial expansions included buying Guelders from its duke Arnold and Ferrette from Archduke Sigismund of Austria. After slaughtering the garrison of Grandson despite its capitulation, this leader lost the Battle of Murat when his troops were caught by surprise while collecting their pay. This leader regained the territories of Boulogne and Ponthieu after the Treaty of Conflans. After this leader’s death, his daughter (*) Mary the Rich married the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I. This leader’s conflicts with the Duke of Lorraine, René II, led to a battle in which he and his army were obliterated by Swiss mercenaries near Metz. For 10 points, name this son of Philip the Good and Duke of Burgundy, who died at the Battle of Nancy.

Competing with Perkins & Co, who imported this good from the Ottoman Empire, Russel and Company became the biggest seller of it in one country during the mid-19th century. During the 18th century, a plainer form of this good in a paste called yapian replaced a mixed form called madak. The production of heimi or “black rice”, a form for this good, flourished during the early 20th century despite its labor intensity. A lack of local demand for European products led to the trade of this good, sourced from colonies in (*) India, for silver from private smugglers; this silver was then used to buy goods like tea and silk in Canton for export. After the destruction of 1,000 tons of this good by an Imperial Commissioner in Humen as contraband in 1839 and skirmishes at Kowloon, Lord Palmerston sent an expedition to blockade the Pearl River. For 10 points, name this good, a narcotic which names two conflicts between the Qīng Dynasty and the United Kingdom.

An allegorical map shows the ideals of this movement in the lands north of the “Demarcation Mountains”, which separates them from places like the “Rat Soup” and “Penitentiary” Rivers. In 1850, P.T. Barnum’s American Museum put on over 100 performances of a play in support of this movement. It’s not necessarily related to San Francisco, but a Committee of Fifty met to examine the claims put forward by a branch of an institution supporting this movement led by Mary Hunt. A statue in Washington, D.C. featuring a heron and two intertwined dolphins was donated by Henry Cogswell, a supporter of this movement, and originally dispensed (*) ice water. A riot against a law passed in support of this movement was put down by activist and mayor of Portland, Maine, Neal Dow. One reformer advocated for this movement through “hatchetations”. For 10 points, what was this movement that sought to curb the consumption of alcohol?
tossups.answer: temperance (accept prohibition or other descriptive answers)
tossups.metadata: accept prohibition or other descriptive answers

tossups.question: One leader of a conspiracy in this country was inspired by the Encyclopédie to draw up plans for a class-free republic and later drowned after the San Pedro de Alcantara was shipwrecked. This country, site of the Conspiracy of the Three Antonios, was the birthplace of an independence leader who was the illegitimate son of a man who had earlier been created as “Baron of Ballinar” and appointed as royal governor of this country. Forces led by Juan José Carrera were defeated by Mariano Osorio at the Disaster of Rancagua, ending this country’s (*) Patria Vieja period. This country gained its independence after victories at the battles of Maipú and Chacabuco. The first colonial governor of this country, Pedro de Valdivia, was killed in a battle against the Mapuche. For 10 points, name this South American country whose independence leaders included Bernardo O’Higgins.

According to one author, uris were elephant-sized bulls that attacked any living thing they saw, which lived in the forests beyond this river. Ammianus Marcellinus described the raid of a city on this river in 368 CE by the chieftain Rando. In his writings, Gregory of Tours moved the site of the martyrdom of the possibly mythical Theban Legion from Agaunum in modern Switzerland to Colonia Agrippensium, a city on this river. Roman settlement along this river is currently exhibited in the archaeological park of (*) Xanten, which had earlier been besieged by the forces of Gaius Julius Civilis during the Batavian Revolt. Two bridges were constructed across this river by Julius Caesar to intimidate hostile tribes like the Suebi who lived on its eastern shore. For 10 points, what is this river, which marked the farthest extent of Roman control of Germania?
